 In a 2004 paper presented to the American Statistical Association, IRS economists Michael Strudler and Tom Petska calculated percentiles data that included both income taxes and Social Security taxes. In 1999, the top 1 percent paid 23.3 percent of combined payroll and income taxes, the top 10 percent paid 52.2 percent, and the top 20 percent paid 68.2 percent.
 
 In recent years, a number of foreign countries have also started publishing tax-share data. They show the same trend of higher and higher burdens on the wealthy even when tax rates are cut sharply.
 
 For example, according to Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs, the share of total income taxes paid by the top 1 percent of taxpayers was 11 percent in the United Kingdom in 1979, when the top income-tax rate was 83 percent. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher cut that rate to 60 percent and by 1987 the share of income taxes paid by the top 1 percent had risen to 14 percent. The top rate was cut again to 40 percent, where it still stands, and the share of income taxes paid by the top 1 percent continued rising to a current level of 21 percent.

 If by equal ye mean some even predisposition, I believe that this is not genetically the case. There are any number of genetic tests which would this unequality. The midget will never dunk on Karl Malone, I'm sorry to tell ye.
 
 If by equal ye mean some infinite strand of probablilities for success based on environment, random chance, etc, you would be hard pressed to guarantee environmental equality. 
 
 Once a child moves from the amniotic environment and is placed on mum's lap, the inequality begins. The parents of one child are PhDs, while the parents of the other are fascinated by shiny objects. It does not take Adam Smith to determine an unbalanced equation. 
 
 I hesitate to mention also the ramifications abortion brings to the equation. We really have no way of knowing if the next Einstein met a rather premature fate due to an unfortunate roll of the parental dice. So we have determined that not all pregnancies are equal, viz a viz abortion, mortality rates, etc...
 
 And yet, traveling back, and taking stock of the genetic material the parents bring we find that even conception is unequal. If your ancestors were rather slow and dimwitted, chances are they became Sabre tooth lunch before having the opportunity to develop the unique genetic pattern that would someday become ye. That being said, there are a number of people I have met in my travels who suggest that perhaps the sabre tooth's were not perfect hunters after all as apparently some rather slow dim-witted proto-folks survived. 
 
 Fast forward through the ages and we find ourselves with no natural predation with the attendant increased survival rates of genetic traits that would normally be disposed by predation. As the gene pool broadens, there are progressively larger deviations from the standard. These standard deviants are, by nature, by definition, unequal. There is nothing unnatural about it. 
 
 But the question remains: Should all people, regardless of ability be treated equally? This question has been answered for generations on the playgrounds of America by the adherents of the game Dodge Ball. Whether the predator is a sabre tooth or a round rubber ball, nature is a cruel judge of equality.
 
 So then, equality is not genetic, it is not mathematical, it is not natural. In theory, the only place we observe attempted equality is in society. But not all societies are equal. Society itself is replete with examples of inequality. The male teenager pays higher insurance rates than the mother of 2. The person with the low credit score receives a different interest rate than the high score holder. Inequality is just as easily self assigned as it is conferred by the society. The individual's decision making process has wide ranging implications on how that individual is adjudged by society. Is the fool and the wise man judged equally? Should they be?
 
 Equality as a societal value would appear to be a rather recent invention. The pyramids, the Great Wall of China, the American railroads; these enterprises were not constructed by a group of peers. As our own notions of equality evolve, we find ourselves in continual conflict over what constitutes equality. Why should A equal B? What is the logic? What is the value? In large part this discussion involves two parties, the one - an actual or professed lesser, the other - an actual or professed greater. The former has a natural desire to elevate where the latter sees only denegration of the self in according equality to another. 
 
 As a society, we profess to value equality. At the same time, the profusion of media offerings on the "top 100" this or "Worlds most___" that, testify that in reality, it is a natural inclination to rank and to assign position to ones self and one's peers. It is not enough to know our credit score, we want to know where that score ranks in society. What percentage of the population has a higher IQ? How does the MAJORITY feel about X issue. As a social animal, it is in our nature to determine our place in society, to not settle for equality but rather strive to be the alpha. To be perfectly cynical, I believe that it is best for the individual to APPEAR to care about equality, while in reality, working to strengthen and advance one's position. Who among you when asking for a raise has ever asked the boss to ensure that the raise is the same as the one for everyone else?
 
 Equality then appears to be nothing more than some unreachable ideal, like pi calculated out to infinity. We may not reach equality, but we can try to shrink the bell curve.

 But recent studies of military demographics suggest that today's military is neither uneducated nor poor. Statistically, the enlisted ranks of the military are drawn mainly from neighborhoods that are slightly more affluent than the norm. The very poor are actually underrepresented in the military, relative to the number of very poor people in the population. 
 
 That's mainly because the military won't accept the lowest academic achievers. The Army limits recruits without high school degrees to 3 1/2 % of the pool, for instance, while the Marines won't accept recruits without high school degrees. Poverty correlates strongly with high school dropout rates, so these rules significantly limit the access of the very poor to military service. 
 
 At the same time, they ensure that enlisted members of the military are more likely than members of the general population to have high school degrees. The same pattern holds for commissioned officers. In 2004, for instance, only 4.2% of officers lacked college degrees, and a whopping 37% held an advanced degree of some sort, compared to only 10% of adults nationwide.
